timeline.summary: An email chain discusses obtaining RSA tokens for access to Relativity, a web-based mass-document management system. A form needs to be completed and sent to a recipient for RSA token issuance. A Relativity database is being set up for the U.S. v. Epstein case, specifically requesting the upload of PDF files from the “USvEpstein-awestigation FBI materials” folder (reports, FOIA documents) while excluding files from a subfolder. There's an expectation of receiving a large volume of case files and a need for agent access to avoid delays. A privilege review isn't anticipated for the initial materials.

On July 8, 2019, an Associate U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent an indictment and detention memorandum related to Jeffrey Epstein’s case (U.S. v. Epstein) to [REDACTED]. The documents were attached to an email chain initiated by [REDACTED].

Marc Fernich sent a government memorandum regarding the detention of Jeffrey Epstein to Martin Weinberg and copied Judge Pitman’s chambers and Judge Berman’s chambers. The memorandum was attached to an email sent in advance of an expected bail argument in U.S. v. Epstein, 19 Cr. 490 (RMB), presented by Judge Berman.

Reid Weingarten sent contact information for the U.S. Attorney’s team involved in the case *U.S. v. Epstein* to be used as a point of contact for Mr. Epstein. The information included multiple office and cell phone numbers belonging to Assistant U.S. Attorneys from the Southern District of New York.

Emails dated July 8, 2019, discuss the U.S. v. Epstein case (19 Cr. 490). An arrest team has been notified. Pretrial services requested a memorandum outlining the government’s rationale for denying conditions of release for the defendant, which was attached. An Assistant U.S. Attorney responded to the request for the memorandum. The document was subsequently redacted by NYSPT/02/USCOURTS.

Marc Fernich is attempting to retrieve items taken from Jeffrey Epstein’s person upon arrest, specifically Epstein’s phone, cash, and other belongings. He is coordinating with a Special Agent, who advises him to contact the case agent directly. A government memorandum regarding detention in the case U.S. v. Epstein was sent to the Chambers of Judge Pitman, with defense and Berman chambers copied. Marc Fernich is seeking confirmation of the number to contact the case agent and is awaiting coordination regarding the retrieval of the items.

Roberta Kaplan, representing a client, contacted multiple individuals, including Jenna Dabbs and Alexandra Elenowitz-Hess, regarding the Crime Victims' Rights Act (18 U.S.C. 3771(a)(4)) in the case of *U.S. v. Epstein*. Kaplan offered to have her client heard at a bail hearing and proposed various methods of communication, such as a submission or inclusion in a bail submission. She suggested a brief call to discuss the matter, noting her team’s travel schedule. An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent a follow-up email emphasizing the confidential nature of the communication.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York contacted Roberta Kaplan and a team at Kaplan Hecker & Fink LLP regarding the bail hearing in *U.S. v. Epstein*. The Attorney informed the recipients that, under 18 U.S.C. 3771(a)(4) of the Crime Victims' Rights Act, the victim has the right to be reasonably heard at certain public proceedings, including those involving release. They offered to discuss this with the team and potentially include a submission or representation regarding the victim’s desired input in the bail hearing. The email also contained a standard confidentiality notice.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York contacted Isidro Garcia regarding the bail hearing in *U.S. v. Epstein*. The Attorney informed Garcia that, under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (18 U.S.C. 3771(a)(4)), the victim has the right to be reasonably heard at relevant proceedings, including bail hearings. They offered to include a victim’s input in the bail submission and expressed an intention to vigorously oppose bail.

Travel authorization 10415581 was approved for a trip to West Palm Beach, FL, from 2019-07-11 to 2019-07-14, related to “U.S. v. Epstein (2018R0618) - Victim Interviews.” The authorization is currently pending further approval. Links to E2 Single Sign On and Manual Login are provided for the DOJ Network. The email includes reference ID# T0007 and a disclaimer regarding confidential information.

Email notification regarding final approval of voucher 10416822-1(1) for a trip to West Palm Beach, FL, from 2019-07-11 to 2019-07-12. The purpose of the trip was victim interviews related to the U.S. v. Epstein case (2018R01618). The voucher total expenses were $779.97, with an estimated trip cost of $1050.66. The voucher status is awaiting payment. Relevant login links and contact information for support are provided.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York sent an email regarding the U.S. v. Epstein case (19 Cr. 490). The email discussed the Crime Victims’ Rights Act (18 U.S.C. 3771(a)(4)) and the victim’s right to be reasonably heard at bail hearings. The Attorney offered to discuss with the recipients whether the client wished to submit a statement or representation for inclusion in the bail submission, emphasizing it was voluntary. The Attorney proposed a brief call to discuss this further, noting their limited availability due to team travel.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York contacted Roberta Kaplan, Jenna Dabbs, and Alexandra Elenowitz-Hess regarding the bail hearing in *U.S. v. Epstein*. The Attorney explained that under 18 U.S.C. 3771(a)(4) of the Crime Victims’ Rights Act, victims have the right to be reasonably heard at certain public proceedings, including those involving release decisions. The Attorney offered to discuss whether the clients wished to submit information or representations for inclusion in the bail submission, noting their intention to vigorously oppose bail. A brief call was proposed for the following day to discuss this matter.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent a courtesy copy of the Government’s response to a defendant’s motion regarding a sealing request in the case *U.S. v. Epstein* (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). Defense counsel was copied on the communication.

An email chain discusses the Crime Victims’ Rights Act (18 U.S.C. 3771(a)(4)) in the case of *U.S. v. Epstein*. An Assistant U.S. Attorney is contacting individuals, including Roberta Kaplan, to explore whether the victims involved in the case would like to be heard at a bail hearing and to discuss including their input in the bail submission. The email emphasizes the victims’ right to be reasonably heard and offers to discuss the matter further. A standard confidentiality disclaimer is included.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York contacted Roberta Kaplan, Jenna Dabbs, and Alexandra Elenowitz-Hess regarding the bail hearing in *U.S. v. Epstein*. The Attorney cited 18 U.S.C. 3771(a)(4) of the Crime Victims’ Rights Act, noting the victims’ right to be reasonably heard at public proceedings, particularly those involving release. They offered to include any victim input – through submission, representation in the bail submission, or discussion – and suggested a brief call to discuss this option. The Attorney indicated they would be available for a call the following day.

Email communication regarding final voucher 10416822-1(1), approved for a trip to West Palm Beach, FL, from 2019-07-11 to 2019-07-12 for the purpose of victim interviews in the U.S. v. Epstein case. The voucher total expenses were $779.97, with an estimated trip cost of $1050.66. The email provides links to E2 Single Sign On and E2 Manual Login for expense tracking. It also includes standard disclaimers regarding confidential information and email notification management.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding a late travel voucher (Voucher for Trip 10416822) for Trip ID: 1041611. The trip details include Destination: West Palm Beach, Purpose: R19NYS 13654 - U.S. v. Epstein (2018R01618) - Victim Interviews, Travel Dates: 2019-07-11 - 2019-07-12, and Current Status: Authorization Approved. The recipient is instructed to submit the voucher and mark it as Final if no additional expenses are due.  The email provides links to E2 Single Sign On and E2 Manual Login for expense reporting. A reference ID# V0013 is included, along with standard confidentiality warnings.

The document is a series of emails regarding the bail hearing for Ghislaine Maxwell’s case (U.S. v. Epstein). It involves communication between Roberta Kaplan (representing the victim), Jenna Dabbs, Alexandra Elenowitz-Hess, and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the victim's rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act. The Assistant U.S. Attorney offers to discuss options for the victim to be heard at the bail hearing, including submitting information or a representation, but emphasizes that it’s not a requirement. The emails suggest a desire to accommodate the victim’s rights while also maintaining flexibility regarding timing and participation.

Martin Weinberg, attorney for the defense in the case *U.S. v. Epstein*, requested a copy of records obtained from Institution 1, specifically financial records, to be produced as part of Rule 16 discovery and not as a public filing. A government attorney responded with a copy of the government’s detention memo and exhibits filed that afternoon in support of the government's position regarding Epstein’s bail. The request focused on a one-month period surrounding the time of two wire transfers.

v. Epstein case (19 Cr. 490). *   Reid Weingarten, a defense attorney, is coordinating with government counsel ([REDACTED]) and Judge Berman’s chambers. *   Discussions revolve around the government's bail memorandum and the defendant’s motion for bail. *   Attendees express availability for meetings on Monday morning, with a proposed agenda. *   The government provided an attached document (Government’s reply in support of its detention memo and in opposition to the defendant’s motion for bail) filed this afternoon.

v. Epstein (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). *   There are multiple email exchanges discussing scheduling a meeting to discuss the case, particularly regarding a visit to Reid Weingarten following the hearing. *   The government expresses a willingness to speak with Weingarten on Monday morning, contingent on a general understanding of the client’s priorities. *   The government provided the bail memorandum and supporting exhibits to Judge Berman. *   There's a request to ensure all parties are kept informed via communication to account for varying team availability.

Martin G. Weinberg, Esq., requested a copy of records obtained from Institution 1 for the U.S. v. Epstein case, requesting they be provided as discovery rather than a public filing.  A U.S. Attorney attached the Government's reply and exhibits in support of the detention memo and opposition to the defendant's motion for bail to Judge Berman.  Communication occurred between Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, and the Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the discovery process.

The attached document is a courtesy copy of the Government’s request to Judge Berman for the exclusion of speedy trial time in the case of *U.S. v. Epstein*, from July 15, 2019, to July 18, 2019. Defense counsel consents to this request.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent photographs to Mike regarding the case *U.S. v. Epstein* (19 Cr. 490 [RMB]). The Attorney confirmed that pages 6 and 7 of the relevant document were blank and were not photographed.

Martin Weinberg inquired about the availability of the original documents related to the U.S. v. Epstein case (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). Mike, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York, attached photographs and stated that pages 6 and 7 were blank and unphotographed.

Michael Miller of Steptoe & Johnson LLP communicated with the U.S. Attorney’s Office regarding the U.S. v. Epstein case (19 Cr. 490). The communication outlined plans to respond to court questions without introducing new facts and to attempt to obtain and review the defendant’s passport and physical evidence. Photographs were attached, noting that pages 6 and 7 of a document were blank and not photographed.

An email chain concerning the case “U.S. v. Epstein” is being distributed between Michael C. Miller of Steptoe & Johnson LLP and various recipients, including Reid Weingarten, Martin G. Weinberg, Michael Scavelli, Morgan Lucas, Jim Brochin, and Jason Meade. The email contains an attached letter and includes standard legal disclaimers regarding confidential and privileged information.

Michael C. Miller, a partner at Steptoe & Johnson LLP, sent a letter regarding the case “U.S. v. Epstein” to Michael Scavelli, Jim Brochin, Martin G. Weinberg, Morgan Lucas, Jason Meade, and others. The letter is attached as a PDF named “Discovety_Letter_Aug_1,_2019_-c2.pdf”. The email contains a standard confidentiality notice from Steptoe & Johnson LLP.

Michael Miller of Steptoe & Johnson LLP sent an email to Judge Berman’s chambers regarding a Government motion for an order of nolle prosequi in the case *U.S. v. Epstein* (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). The email included a courtesy copy of the Government’s motion and was copied to defense counsel. An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent the initial email.

A letter motion for an order of nolle prosequi was sent by the Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York to Judge Berman’s chambers in the case of *U.S. v. Epstein* (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). The letter, attached with a proposed order, was submitted following a previous discussion and was copied to defense counsel, Martin Weinberg and Michael Miller.

The document consists of email correspondence regarding a motion for an order of nolle prosequi in the case of *U.S. v. Epstein* (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). Emails between attorneys from the Southern District of New York’s U.S. Attorney’s Office and Judge Berman’s chambers detail the submission of a Government letter motion and a proposed order requesting court approval for the nolle prosequi. Defense counsel is copied on the correspondence.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney is requesting Marty Weinberaer to return all discovery received in the case of *U.S. v. Epstein* and certify its destruction or deletion. This is to ensure no outstanding discovery obligations exist for the hearing on Tuesday and to comply with the protective order. The Attorney anticipates a brief meeting with Weinberaer at 12:30 PM, followed by a call around 12:45 PM – 1:00 PM.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York is following up with Marty Weinberg regarding the U.S. v. Epstein case. The Attorney is inquiring about the defense’s intentions regarding addressing the dismissal and the status of the return of discovery materials. Specifically, the Attorney requests that Weinberg return all received discovery materials to the government, either through security destruction/deletion or certification of deletion, to ensure no outstanding discovery obligations exist for the court hearing on Tuesday.

This document is a letter from U.S. District Judge Richard M. Berman to Professor Bruce A. Green regarding Green’s expert opinion and opinion piece concerning the U.S. v. Epstein case. Green was retained as an expert on legal ethics and provided an affidavit recommending the disqualification of David Boies from representing Ghislaine Maxwell. Judge Berman expresses surprise that this recommendation wasn't disclosed alongside Green’s opinion piece and questions Green’s interpretation of Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 57 and the Crime Victims' Rights Act, arguing the piece may have attempted to silence Maxwell and Boies. The letter is copied to Martin G. Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, and David Boies.
